In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The key procurement principles in the Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from 
time to time) and the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time) 
of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) are (i) eligibility, (ii) economy and efficiency, (iii) fairness, 
(iv) transparency, and (v) promotion of domestic industries. The business opportunities outreach 
initiatives (BOOI) proposed in this regional capacity development technical assistance (TA) will 
benefit developing member countries by enhancing competition in ADB-financed procurement 
and recruitment of consultants, promoting cost-effectiveness, and building capacity.1 They will 
also reinforce ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) which aims to (i) support 
competitive markets and effective public administration, (ii) support explicit anticorruption efforts 
and combat fraud and corruption, and (iii) ensure that all individuals and firms involved in ADB-
financed projects adhere to the highest ethical standards.  
 
2.  Significant portions of ADB loan, grant, and TA proceeds are used to fund procurement 
of goods, works, and consultant services. In order to be successful in ADB-funded projects, 
contractors and consultants need to (i) be aware of how to locate and pursue ADB business 
opportunities, and (ii) become familiar with ADB procurement policies and procedures. The 
BOOI will provide a range of tools to support potential contractors and consultants to gain this 
knowledge. 
 
3.  Typically,  national  chambers  of  commerce,  consulting  and  contractor  associations, 
federations of industries, and ministries of trade have approached ADB through its Board of 
Directors to provide BOOI. To date, this has been limited to conducting business opportunities 
seminars in ADB member countries. The demand for seminars has been increasing, especially 
in borrowing member countries, where national industries strive to increase their participation in 
ADB-financed  projects.  In  nonborrowing  member  countries,  the  recent  financial  crisis  has 
increased the interest of contractors and consultants in either establishing or consolidating their 
business relationships with ADB. 
 
4.   This TA will expand the scope of BOOI interventions by adopting a more proactive and 
systematic approach to supporting contractor and consultant access to public sector contracting 
opportunities funded by ADB over a 3-year period from March 2010 to December 2012.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
5.   Although  the  business  opportunities  seminars  and  the  more  recent  business 
opportunities fair2 have been useful information-sharing and public relations events, there is a 
need to broaden the tools available to respond to clients' needs and to monitor the effect of 
these initiatives.  
 
6.  The need to develop a wider range of BOOI tools is driven by (i) changes in the global 
business environment, (ii) the emergence and availability of new information technologies, and 
(iii) more sophisticated client needs. This requires a variety of tailor-made BOOI tools so ADB 
can be more effective and efficient in addressing the demands of the business community.   
 
7.  Since  1985,  over  13,000  prospective  suppliers,  manufacturers,  contractors,  and 
consultants have attended 263 seminars in 34 member countries. The seminars have been

2 
demand-driven. Although participants have consistently reported that they found the seminars to 
be generally successful, the efficiency and effectiveness of this approach has been difficult to 
assess and baseline data have not been collected. The TA will redress this by establishing a 
monitoring and evaluation framework with indicators measuring: (i) the quality of specific ADB 
BOOI-sponsored events, (ii) the quality of host organization support for ADB BOOI initiatives, 
and  (iii)  the  effect  on  participation  by  contractors  and  consultants  and  the  quality  of  the 
preparation of their bids and proposals. It is proposed that ADB will conduct pre- and post-event 
surveys and annual electronic questionnaires to survey BOOI participants, host organizations, 
industry associations, and professional groups. An expert in electronic time-based surveying will 
be engaged to help develop an appropriate electronic platform, including survey tools that can 
be used to monitor the BOOI effectively.  
 
8.  The TA framework is presented in Appendix 1. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The outcome will be high-quality competitive bids and proposals for the supply of goods 
and works, and consulting services from suppliers, contractors, and consulting firms in ADB 
member  countries.  The  impact  of  the  TA  will  be  greater  competition  among  suppliers, 
contractors, and consulting firms for procurement under ADB-funded projects in its member 
countries.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The outcome will be achieved through three outputs. The first will be that suppliers, 
contractors, and consulting firms in ADB member countries will be advised on how to locate 
business opportunities with ADB. ADB and its member countries will conduct 40 business 
opportunities seminars whose location will be demand-driven and determined in consultation 
with members of ADB Board of Directors, among others. However, it is expected that a seminar 
will not normally be held more than once a year in a member country.33The host organization 
will provide the venue, promote the event, and invite participants. Seminars will be sequenced 
where practicable to ensure resources are used efficiently. Business opportunities fairs will 
normally be hosted annually by ADB in its headquarters or in the region. They will provide a 
one-stop forum and networking event for contractors, consultants, suppliers, and ADB staff.  
 
11.  On  a  case-by-case  basis,  opportunities  will  be  taken  to  couple  BOOI  with  "anchor 
events" in the contracting and/or consulting industry to maximize audience attendance and 
exposure to ADB. Anchor events will be either sector-based (e.g., energy, transport) or theme-
based (e.g., public–private partnerships, environment) events such as conferences, conventions, 
forums,  fairs,  or  exhibitions.  ADB  Central  Operations  Services  Office  (COSO),  in  close 
cooperation with resident missions, the Regional and Sustainable Development Department, 
communities of practice, and regional departments, will identify and develop a list of preferred 
anchor events by region or country for which BOOI are targeted.

12.  The second output will be an improved ADB business opportunities website that will 
provide relevant information on business opportunities under ADB-financed projects to suppliers, 
contractors,  and  consulting  firms.  This  will  be  achieved  by  upgrading  the  website  and 
implementing a web-based BOOI monitoring tool. This will include recording feedback from 
participants  so  ADB  has  a  better  understanding  of  the  kind  of  information  requirements 
contractors and consultants have and what they would like to have covered by BOOI events so 
ADB service delivery quality can be further improved.  
 
13.  The third output will be web-based BOOI training materials, and an efficient, web-based 
BOOI monitoring and evaluation tool. This will be implemented at ADB headquarters with the 
assistance of consultants. The target audience for the BOOI training materials will be staff 
working at manufacturers, suppliers, exporters, trading houses, contractors and consultants, 
universities,  nongovernment  organizations,  embassies,  ministries  of  trade,  chambers  of 
commerce, federations of industries, contractors and consultants associations, and government 
officials involved in ADB-financed projects.  
 
14.  Depending on the nature and intent of a specific BOOI, the training materials may cover 
all  or  a  selection  of  the  following  topics:  (i)  ADB's  mission,  organization,  and  operations;  
(ii) ADB’s project cycle, and the opportunities that exist at each stage of the cycle; (iii) the 
provision of advance information about forthcoming business opportunities as contained on the 
ADB website; in news releases, bid invitations in local newspapers, and on other websites; and 
in procurement notices in United Nations Development Business;44(iv) aspects associated with 
the  recruitment  of  consultants,  including  registration,  expressions  of  interest,  short-listing 
procedures, requests for proposals, preparation of competitive technical proposals, preparation 
of financial proposals, contract negotiations, and contract administration; (v) aspects associated 
with the procurement of goods and works by the borrower, including prequalification, use of 
standard bidding documents, procurement methods and procedures, preparation of responsive 
bids, public bid opening, bid evaluation, and application of domestic preference; (vi) ADB’s 
Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) and the investigative process and sanctions; 
(vii) redress procedures; (viii) procedures for the disbursement of funds to suppliers of goods, 
works, and services; and (ix) contractors' and consultants' success stories under ADB-financed 
contracts. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund 
(TASF-IV). The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,000,000 equivalent. The cost estimates 
and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.   ADB is the executing agency for this TA. Disbursements under the TA will be done in 
accordance  with  the  ADB's  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook.5  Individual 
consultants will be recruited under the TA in accordance with the ADB's Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants (1997, as amended from time to time).

17.  The COSO business opportunities team will organize business opportunities seminars 
and a business opportunities fairs, coordinate and participate in anchor events, maintain the 
business opportunities website, submit annual work plans related to business opportunities, and 
collate annual statistics and data relevant to measuring BOOI performance. Consultants will 
assist the COSO business opportunities team with the (i) handling of logistical aspects of the 
BOOI, (ii) improvements to the ADB business opportunities website, (iii) development of related 
web-based BOOI training materials, and (iv) development of an efficient, web-based BOOI 
monitoring  and  evaluation  tool.  The  outline  terms  of  reference  for  these  consultants  is  in 
Appendix 3. 
 
18.  For  business  opportunities  seminars  and  anchor  events,  host  organizers  will  be 
responsible  for  all  local  arrangements,  such  as  providing  conference  rooms,  audiovisual 
equipment, and secretarial assistance, and the issuing of advertisements and invitations to 
interested participants. The host organizers may charge a nominal attendance fee to cover 
these costs, including rental of conference rooms and lunch. Participants will be responsible for 
their own travel and accommodation costs. ADB will provide the resource speakers and seminar 
documents for participants. Members of the ADB Board of Directors normally help ADB to  
contact relevant organizations in the member countries represented by their constituencies.  
 
19.  Business  opportunities  seminars  are  usually  requested  through  the  ADB  Board  of 
Directors. In response to such requests, COSO communicates with the host organization and 
designs and plans the seminar in close cooperation with the organizers to suit their particular 
needs and preferences. Seminars are conducted in English. The standard format recommended 
by COSO spans 2 days; on the first day, the seminar is held and on the second individual 
interviews take place with the resource speakers. On the first day, there is usually a morning 
plenary  session,  after  which  the  participants  divide  into  two  groups:  an  industry  group 
(contractors, suppliers, and manufacturers) and a consultants group. Typical requests to amend 
this  standard  format  to  suit  the  needs  of  a  particular  organization  include  (i)  conducting 
condensed  presentations  in  consecutive  sessions  rather  than  concurrently;  (ii)  including 
presentations on ADB's private sector and/or cofinancing operations; (iii) emphasizing particular 
sectors,  countries,  and  topics  during  the  presentations;  and  (iv) having  abbreviated 
presentations but longer individual meetings or round table discussions. 
 
20.  For business opportunities fairs, ADB will provide the venue, resource speakers, and 
presentation materials. ADB staff will be available to conduct one-on-one meetings. The event 
will be advertised on ADB's business opportunities website and details will be given on the 
program and logistics. The website will incorporate an online registration system. Feedback and 
recommendations of participants attending the first business opportunities fair will be taken into 
consideration in the planning of future events. Participants will be responsible for their own 
travel and accommodation costs.  
 
21.  The proposed use of anchor events as an additional BOOI tool will be carefully assessed 
on a case-by-case basis, using agreed criteria to ensure the events are complementary and the 
link with the anchor event adds value. Criteria for the identification of suitable anchor events 
may include the following: (i) events are well publicized, (ii) the theme of the event is consistent 
with business opportunities offered by ADB, (iii) the participant profile fits the target group for 
ADB business opportunities, (iv) there are opportunities for meaningful interaction between ADB 
representatives and interested participants, and (v) the organizers have experience of delivering 
well-organized events.

5 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis 
for Business Opportunities Outreach Initiatives, 2010–2012, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Web Development Specialist (national, 7 person-months)   
1.  Duties. The national consultant will report to the technical assistance (TA) administering 
officer in the Central Operations Services Office (COSO) of the Asian Development Bank and 
carry out the following tasks: 
(i)  Design and develop better navigational tools in the Business Opportunities page to 
improve user access across various content areas of the website. 
(ii)  Integrate the contents of Consulting Services and Procurement pages. 
(iii)  Improve links to the projects information website in adb.org. 
(iv)  Develop a user-friendly portal comprising consulting and procurement opportunities. 
(v)  Redefine  the  navigation  within  the  Projects  and  Opportunities  –  Business 
Opportunities pages in the ADB website. 
(vi)  Reclassify the contents of Business Opportunities page to provide a one-stop-shop 
and address the needs of external parties such as suppliers, contractors, bidders 
and consultants. 
(vii)  Implement  better  handling  of  information/data  that  is  common  for  Business 
Opportunities and Projects. 
(viii)  Coordinate with appropriate COSO and Department of External Relations (DER) 
staff on the contents of the pages. 
(ix)  Implement the proposed designs in coordination with DER's web programmers and 
webmaster. 
 
2.  Expertise and qualifications. The consultant will have a university degree, ideally in 
information technology or engineering, and preferably at least 5 years’ work experience in a web 
development role. As well as the minimum qualifications, the following expertise and experience 
are expected: 
(i)  Demonstrated familiarity with the IBM e-Business suite, and/or similar platforms. 
(ii)  Demonstrated familiarity with Web 2.0 collaboration systems. 
 
3.  The duration of the assignment will be over a 2-year period. 
 
 
B.  Web Designer (national, 6 person-months)   
4.  Duties. The national consultant will report to the TA administering officer in COSO and 
carry out the following tasks: 
(i)         Development of Business Opportunities web-based training materials 
   
(a)  Enhance and finalize the working copy of the interactive courseware based on  
feedback from the business opportunities fair and from pilot testing within 
COSO. 
(b)  Integrate  the  interactive  courseware  with  the  COSO  section  of  the  ADB 
website for use by firms as well as COSO portal for use of new COSO staff. 
(c)  Create a reproducible version of this interactive courseware to be distributed 
on CDs, flash drives or other electronic media during seminars, etc.

courseware (dollar amounts, statistics, etc.) 
(e)  Train at least 2 COSO staff in maintaining and updating the information in the

(f)  Coordinate and satisfy the requirement of the Office of Information System

5.  Expertise and qualifications. The consultant will have a university degree, ideally in

development role. As well as the minimum qualifications, the following expertise and experience 
are expected: 
(i)  Demonstrated familiarity with the IBM e-Business suite, and/or similar platforms. 
(ii)  Demonstrated familiarity with Web 2.0 collaboration systems. 
 
6.  The duration of the assignment will be over a 2-year period.

(ii)  Assistance in the processing of project proposals under the TA; 
(iii)  Logistics for conferences, workshops, and meetings—organizing venue, making
